newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Checkpoint seeks broader base.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Checkpoint seeks broader base.

text.p: CheckPoint Software Technologies Ltd plans to grow its position in the network security field by broadening its customer base, decreasing its reliance on Sun Microsystems Inc and exploring acquisitions.

"We hope to continue to grow market share, primarily by continuing to aggresively expand our distribution," said Deborah Triant, president and chief executive of Checkpoint Software Technologies Inc, the Israeli-based company's U.S. unit.

According to research firm International Data Corp, Checkpoint already commands a 40 percent chunk of the global market for firewalls, which is software that enforces the boundarys between networks and protects computers against unauthorized users or destructive virus programs.
Checkpoint's flagship product, Firewall-1, is distributed as an embedded program in hardware sold by firms such as Sun Microsystems, Bay Networks Inc, Xylan Corp and Hewlett-Packard Co.
Triant said it wants to shrink its reliance on Sun Microsystems, which bundles the firewall software with its computers and also sells it separately under the product name SunSoft.

CheckPoint's stock prices, now trading near $25 per share, fell by about 15 percent during one session last week after an analyst said revenue from Sun fell to $2.7 million in the third quarter from $3.8 million in the second.
"We wanted it to shrink," she added. "Not because we want Sun to reduce their sales, but because we want to grow other channels so much faster."

"That (the shrinking Sun revenue), for us, was very good news," Triant said, adding that the percentage of Sun revenue in the third quarter dropped to 34 percent from 57 percent in the first quarter and CheckPoint still exceded analysts' expectations.

She added that company could also grow through acquisitions. "We will likely grow by aquisition as well, and any acquisition we make will be technology focused to continue to add complimentary technology into our product as well," Triant said.
IDC predicts the firewall market will expand from $160 million in 1995 to $979 million in the year 2000, with total units shipped rising to 1.5 million then, from about 10,000 in 1996.
Checkpoint says the expansion of the Internet and intranets as business tools and the exponential growth of the computer market means certain growth for firewall makers.
"There are still a lot of companies that still are not using firewalls, and then there is growth available within the companies themselves," Triant said.
She explained that, while some firms have only simple security concerns, those with users logging in from remote locations and multiple internal networks often need numerous separate firewalls.
To reach those companies, Checkpoint intends to increase its sales by resellers, or vendors who sell the product to customers, often under a different name.

"We are also aggressively signing new OEM (original equipment manufacturers) partners, to get a very broad distribution of the product," Triant said. "I expect OEM sales will grow as a percentage of revenues."
CheckPoint third quarter 1996 earnings, at $0.10 cents per share, beat concensus expectations by about one cent a share.
